comments.text:
+Disgruntled Goat what you mentioned is a promising new form of gene 
therapy. rewriting a virus's genetic code so instead of making cells 
produce viruses it modifies the cell's code. there are some problems with 
this too, however namely that the viruses need their own code to reproduce 
and that viruses are able to pull some tricks medical science hasn't quite 
figured out, but the worst problem I can see with this is that to modify 
one's immune system we would need a virus that targets the immune system to 
start with. and those are usually the worst kind such as ebola or HIV
and what you are talking about could be considered a vaccine for bacteria I 
guess.
comments.author: Mighty Tighty Whitey And I'm Smuggling Plums

comments.text:
+Samrules888 What? Vaccines work against both viral and bacterial diseases. 
In fact they work against pretty much every kind of infectious disease.
comments.author: Disgruntled Goat

comments.text:
+Disgruntled Goat
vaccines are for viruses. this is about antibiotics.
comments.author: Mighty Tighty Whitey And I'm Smuggling Plums

comments.text:
+Samrules888 Or use a virus to inject genetic code into the patient's cells 
which then multiply and carry the gene with them. Nobody has managed to 
make gene therapy work very well. There are a few successful cases that 
repaired genetic disorders, but not infectious diseases. It doesn't work 
most of the time and it doesn't seem like the best way to deal with 
diseases. To change the immune system genetically, the genes inside bone 
marrow and the thymus gland would have to be affected, otherwise immune 
cells with the desired traits would not be produced. Vaccines are just an 
easier and better method of dealing with diseases.
comments.author: Disgruntled Goat

comments.text:
Environment* 
If you're going to be scientific then please spell your words right. :)
comments.author: EnigmacTheFirst

comments.text:
+Disgruntled Goat
 there are a number of ways to graft a trait from one specie and put it 
into another. one of the most best methods for something like this is to 
place cell cultures, in this case immune cells into the person which 
continue to grow and multiply and replace the original tissue as long as 
they can be protected from the host body's own immune system.
comments.author: Mighty Tighty Whitey And I'm Smuggling Plums

comments.text:
If you want to copy a species' genetic immunity to something then you would 
need to change a living human's DNA, which is very difficult and doesn't 
work most of the time. Vaccines are a much better approach to dealing with 
diseases.
comments.author: Disgruntled Goat

comments.text:
That is quite true. The way that we measure radiation is very confusing and 
has a lot of what ifs attached to it.
comments.author: KitsuneNiko

comments.text:
+KitsuneNiko To be fair, radiation units confuse me. Roentgens, rads, 
grays, etc....

It doesn't help rads are doses of exposure per kg, but they're often given 
over time. 1000 rads over an hour and over a year are two very different 
things. The time span usually used assumes exposure on the scale of an hour 
or a few hours.
comments.author: seigeengine

comments.text:
Ah thank you @seigeengine. I knew my numbers were minorly-majorly incorrect 
I just didn't know how much. So it's a godsend you could revise my 
information so there could be better clarification.
comments.author: KitsuneNiko

comments.text:
Cockroaches can't survive a nuclear blast, although they are more durable 
to radiation.

And +KitsuneNiko is wrong. The actual results were that 50% of the roaches 
survived at 1000 rads (lethal to Humans), whereas 10% of them survived at 
10000 rads. And the other insects they tested (fruit flies and flour 
beetles) were much more durable, the beetles even withstanding 100000 rads.
comments.author: seigeengine

comments.text:
A nuke would kill cockroaches easily, their resistance to radiation is

top_comment.text:
I am allergic to certain antibiotics, but usually this isn't an issue 
because multiple antibiotics usually work. So what happens if we start 
using one of these compounds that make bugs resistant to other antibiotics 
and some people are allergic to it? ﻿
top_comment.author: mermaidismyname

comments.text:
Ab's a defined by class, if a bacteria is resistant to an Ab of that class, 
then it's a good indication that those bacteria will be resistant to other 
Ab's of that class.  If a bacteria develops resistance against penicillin, 
it's not going to develop resistance against another class, such as 
macrolides (erythromycin).

Also allergies occur once you're exposed to it, simplest way to look at it 
is, if you've never used it, you're not going to know that you're allergic 
to it.  That goes with any other drugs out there.
comments.author: cloudsymph

comments.text:
That's something that antibiotic researchers have to take into account. 
They, and the FDA (in America) have to make sure that not only are they 
safe but also a vast majority of people can take them without an allergic 
reaction.
comments.author: Alex Dayton

comments.author: Kyle Brown

comments.text: yea! fight fire with fire!
comments.author: Savannah Waddell

comments.text:
+AnonymousJon "Even if we find new antimicrobials that work great, won't 
bacteria/viruses just eventually become resistant/immune to those too?"
Not necessarily always the case. Remember the reason why some 
antimicrobials are able to fend off against certain bacteria is because 
they have an innate defense mechanism against them which means that even if 
the bacteria evolve the antimicrobials will likely still be able to defend 
against them because the antimicrobials are naturally able to fight 
new/evolved bacteria..

and yes in some cases microbials may simply become resistant, but that's 
just an example of Darwinism. Biologist may just have to continue searching 
for different ways to fight or eliminate them.
comments.author: StreamerVideo

We live in a bubble of antibiotics and that bubble is popping, we are in a

alternative.

comments.author: looncraz

comments.text:
+Hamboning Allday 

They do not. Bacteria develop resistances through evolutionary pressure. 
They lose these resistances the same way. They don't pass on knowledge. 

In environments where antibiotics are used at sub optimal levels some 
bacteria may survive due to genetic mutations that allow that bacteria to 
resist w/e method that antibacterial uses to kill the bacteria. These 
bacteria will divide and survive at a greater rate than the bacteria killed 
by the antibiotic. This is how you get superbugs.

If there is no more pressure causing bacteria to become resist to a drug, 
they progress normally. Over time the bacteria that have that resistance 
are at a disadvantage (had to give up something or expend more energy for 
that resistance)and will not survive as other as other bacteria. Thus the 
resistant bacteria fade and dwindle.
comments.author: douglasg14b

comments.text:
Douglas does raise a good point because at the level of single celled 
organisms evolution occurs far faster and anything that doesn't confer an 
immediate advantage will pretty much always eventually be entirely removed 
from the gene pool unlike in animal species. Because the extra energy, 
nutrients and time used to make even the slightest amount of extra DNA 
before splitting every time when the DNA offers no advantage significantly 
lowers single celled organisms fitness. 

The problem is this doesn't really occur so much in our bodies because 
bacteria never get to the point where they reach the highest carrying 
capacity of bacteria needed to start killing off all non-perfectly adapted 
organisms. Due to our immune system after determining the bacteria is a 
threat keeping the populations low (reducing the chance of mutations and 
competition for resources).

So any that do spread from one person to the next likely do carry 
resistance given to them by the antibiotics of the first person. And there 
have been hospital found cases where bacteria have been resistant to three 
common antiobiotics so it is a worry.
comments.author: That Spazamataz

comments.text:
Don't bacteria give knowledge of past antibiotics to their future 
generations? I don't think going back to penicillin would be ideal if this 
was the case
comments.author: Hamboning Allday

comments.text:
It is a band aid of sorts, though as we stop using 1 drug and switch to the 
next bacteria become less resistant to the older drug. You could 
essentially have a life cycle of drugs, taking advantage of evolutionary 
pressure on bacteria. As bacteria become resistant to one, you move to the 
next, and keep doing that till you can go full circle and start using the 
first drug again. 

The resistance takes extra energy, bacteria that do not use that extra 
energy will survive more often, this causes the resistance to fade over 
time.
comments.author: douglasg14b

comments.text:
+David Gutowski I think the Quarian's deal was that they lived on sterile 
ships for so long their immune systems just got used to not doing work. I 
don't know how plausible that is, but then again they're a fictional alien 
species so anything goes.
comments.author: Sardonicous1

comments.text:
+Garmo In this case its really not that big of a deal haha. Chemical 
cleansers such as soap/detergent actually physically destroy the cellular 
membrane of bacteria which keeps the cell intact. Although possible it 
would be extremely difficult to develop a resistance to that. Things like 
antiobiotics, however, cant be used to just kill kill kill as their targets 
are inside of us and have the nasty side effect of killing good bacteria 
too, so we sort of use them to try to kill as many as possible without 
damaging the rest of the good bacteria. Obviously, some people worry about 
the good bacteria dying and don't trust their doctors prescription so they 
take too little, and sometimes doctors worry too and underprescribe. It is 
also extremely difficult to completely remove a virus/bacteria from your 
body even after the immune system has determined it as a threat so 
resistant bacterial strains persist for a long time.

The point is its obviously a really big problem and the easiest solution 
would be to just prescribe antibiotics less, but because of its history as 
this wonder drug which has saved millions of lives trying to limit its use 
is fairly difficult. Even when we know that by not limiting its use we are 
digging a hole in the long term.

Classic short sighted humans I guess.

Edit: Sorry about the poor grammar but I just can't be bothered putting in 
effort for youtube comments.
comments.author: That Spazamataz

comments.text:

be fatal.

comments.text:
This is a stop gap to more effective treatments bacteriophage along with 
fast testing would be a lot better but that means developing fast and 
accurate tests which are also cheap.

There are proposed medical devices which could do this kind of testing but 
they are still expensive atm but because of how they could be potentially 
made like CPU's you could bring the price down exponentially over time.

They made by basically cutting very fine groves in a which filter down 
blood into very specific parts also you can use the specific 
electromagnetic properties of certain shapes to filter for certain 
molecules. 

Also you could use active filtering as well because as I said the process 
being used is much like CPU's so what you could do is also use transistor 
sized magnates controlled by a computer to filter out certain molecules, 
viruses and bacteria.

What you would have to do is frist make the groves for the circuitry first 
then it would work much like how CPU's are made then make the groves for 
the liquids to pass though.

comments.author: David Gutowski

comments.text:
Theoretically, no.As a Biologist I must say that there is a defined number 
of mutations a bacteria will withstand until some vital function will be 
compromised and it can no longer reproduce itself, we cannot extrapolate 
from our current knowledge because we know just to little to completely 
understand and define what is actually going on.But statistically you 
remain correct,bacterias,viruses,fungi,unicellular organism have been 
"walking the path of evolution" for way longer than multicellular 
organisms, so enough mutations have accumulated,through time, that they 
have a much higher biological fitness than everyone else. But it is 
actually plausible to understand all their mechanisms so that we can 
actually make ourselves immune to their activities, we just have to 
research and study further into what really happens inside the cells, that 
tricky inner mechanism of life.
comments.author: Draxis32

comments.author: Garmo

comments.text:
Better use of antibiotics is the answer. Resistance often occurs due to 
improper use such as overprescription by doctors or not using the full 
amount. Evolution is a misunderstood concept. Bacteria don't evolve 
resistance too antiobiotics. They start with the resistance (or more 
accurately 1 in a trillion has resistance). If the dosage is low the other 
trillion bacteria will die and the 1 with resistance will multiply 
unimpeded until there are a trillion of it. It is likely that 1 of those 
will have a slightly higher resistance by chance then the others. This 
repeats as the dosage gets higher and higher. However if you just start 
with an extremely high dosage or use a combination of multiple antiobiotics 
or other antibacterials such as garlic, manuka honey etc then you can kill 
the bacteria with resistance as well as the other 1 trillion. 

At the end of the day you are just preventing the inevitable as you said. 
But with the way we use antibiotics at the moment (poorly) antibiotics that 
could provide decent protection for most people for 50 years barely last 
10. So the rate at which we need to find new ones is really out of 
proportion.
comments.author: That Spazamataz

cleaning supplies. For example, many cleaning products have alcohol in 
them, (now kids don't go drinking hand sanitizer that's not how it works)

meaning the cellular makeup are all dead cells. You can't kill dead. 
Although if you were to drink your cleaning supplies... well you know how 
that goes. So yes, antibiotics can be weaker than sanitation, but 
sanitation can be weaker than antibiotics as well. They all have their own 
place and bother are important parts of our health. :)

top_comment.text:
When it comes to fighting disease, I think we're going to find better 
solutions a little closer to home. Specifically, we should be working to 
enhance our own immune systems. Antibiotics unfortunately are not really a 
great solution since they can always adapt to combat them. Our own immune 
systems are a for more adaptable and effective system. What ways are there 
that we can supercharge our white blood cells or increase our immunity? We 
need a solution that is as adaptable as the bugs we are trying to fight.﻿

comments.text:
+Snuffying CML is caused when cells divide and make copies of themselves as 
this process isn't always perfect. Sometimes a pair of chromosomes mixes 
and causes a translocation of chromosome 9 and 22. What causes this though 
is unknown, it just happens and can take anywhere from a few months to a 
few years before you actually start feeling bad. In my case after research 
of blood that was taken in 2009 they found out that I already then had this 
translocation but I got diagnosed in 2011 after a simple coughing that 
lasted for a month or so.

Hope this page can give you some deeper insight: 
http://www.cancer.org/cancer/leukemia-chronicmyeloidcml/detailedguide/leukemia-chronic-myeloid-myelogenous-what-causes

What causes this DNA damage to happen is still unknown; I have read a ton 
of articles saying radiation but at extreme doses (like licking the core 
while wearing a bathing suit), heavy chemicals (forbidden in EU since 
before my birth) and stress.

Lucky it is not hereditary, so now that I am of chemo as a test to see how 
long I can last before it returns, I can have kids and they will be clear.
comments.author: Drazen Jankovic

comments.text:
You have 6104 subscribers. Let me put that into perspective!

If you Human Centipeded all of your subscribers, the length of the 
intestinal tract from the 1st person's mouth to the last person's butthole 
would be 34 miles! or .13% around the Earth!

The biomass (combined weight) of all of your subscribers would be 1.09 
million pounds! or 13.7 fully-loaded 18 wheelers!

If you stacked 6104 Empire state buildings on top of each other, the tower 
would rise to over 1445 miles, or .57% to the moon!

If you drove your car at a speed of 6104 mph, it would take you 4.07 hours 
to travel around the Earth, or 111 years around the largest star in the 
galaxy!

-I hope you enjoyed that! My channel is for deep-thinkers and people that 
enjoy learning about everything the Universe contains. Such as:  the total 
amount of weight of all the bacteria living on your body weighs 4 pounds!

-Being a deep-thinker myself, everyone in my life made me feel like shit 
for thinking too much and not talking enough. Now I embrace it. We all 
should.

Us crazy Yanks just don't like to says the individual letters, and preffer 
to say it as though it is a word.
comments.author: Andrew Combes

captions.text:
Antibiotics are one of humankind's most amazing
discoveries. Ever since that fateful day in

1928 when Scottish physician Alexander Fleming
noticed a funny mold growing in one of his

petri dishes, antibiotics have been kicking
bacterial butt.

That famous mold, of course, was producing
penicillin, the founding antibiotic superstar,

which has since extended the average human
life by at least a decade. It fundamentally

changed the face of medicine. Antibiotics,
or antimicrobials, are basically selective

poisons designed to either kill or slow the
growth of bacteria to the point where your

body's own immune system can clean up. These
drugs target a specific part of bacteria or

some important stage in their development
without damaging the body's host cells. And

they're really great their job. Until they
aren't.

Lately, antibiotic technology has been having
a hard time keeping pace with bacterial evolution.

We've talked here on SciShow about how lots
of your die-hard, go-to favorite antibiotics

are starting to lose their mojo in the face
of sneaky and rapidly evolving bacteria. The

US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
estimates that at least 2,000,000 Americans

became infected with drug-resistant bacteria
in 2012, and 23,000 of them died as a result.

These superbugs are deadly serious and could
quickly unleash a global health crisis if

we don't find a way to keep them in check.
The problem is we've already hit up many of

the most obvious sources of antibiotics, like
fungi, which includes penicillin, and synthetic

molecules.
Fortunately, we humans have big, delicious

brains, and some of the best of them are hard
at work trying to invent all-new ways to kill

dangerous bacteria or find other organisms
on the planet that are better at it than we

are so we can steal their secrets. And while
they're finding some promising leads, I gotta

say, they're looking in some pretty weird
places.
[Intro]

You know how everyone jokes that after some
big global disaster, only cockroaches will

survive? Well, we recently found what may
partially explain their famous, and infuriating,

tenacity. Research from the University of
Nottingham suggests that certain insects,

like roaches and locusts, have brain tissues
that are infused with super-powered antibiotic

juju. The researchers found nine different
antibiotic molecules tucked into the roaches'

nervous systems that may be protecting them
from otherwise lethal bacteria. They're all

a type of molecule known as peptides, short
chains of amino acids that make up proteins,

kinda like proto-proteins. And these peptides
are specific to the bugs' brains. They seem

to be chemicals that roaches'' brain cells
use to communicate with each other, y'know,

whenever a cockroach is sitting around thinking
about stuff, which I guess can happen, and

although we're not sure how these peptides
actually work, laboratory tests have shown

that they're incredibly effective at eliminating
some of our least favorite bacteria, like

the most dangerous strains of e.coli, which
cause gastrointestinal infections. And even

MRSA, a super-resistant type of staphylococcus
bacterium that can cause unstoppable deadly

infections in humans, particularly in hospitals.
In lab trials, these roach brain molecules

killed over 90% of MRSA bacteria, without
harming any host cells.

So I can guess what you're thinking: shut
up and take my money! Well, hold on a sec,

because we're a bit away from having cockroach
brains on the pharmacy shelves. There's still

loads of technical hurdles to overcome, tests
to conduct, basic things we need to figure

out, like how exactly these molecules work.
But roaches aren't the only hardy animals

out there. Alligators are some of the Earth's
most rugged beasts. They essentially live

in cesspool swamps teeming with bacteria and
fungus and other microbes, and more than that,

they're known brawlers. Put just a few territorial
800 pound toothy reptiles together in a dirty

swamp, and you will no doubt come out with
some serious bite marks and bloody wounds,

even missing limbs. But amazingly, what you
probably won't find are any infections. This

got some bayou scientists to thinkin'!
Dr. Mark Merchant, a biochemist at McNeese

State University in Louisiana, helped conduct
a decade long study that investigated what

makes alligators so unusually resistant to
bacterial and fungal infection.

Turns out, it's in their blood. An alligator's
immune system is largely innate, meaning it

can fight off harmful micro-organisms without
having any prior exposure to them. They just

pop right out of their eggs ready to do battle.
We humans also have some innate immunity,

provided by things like our skin and white
blood cells, but a big part of our immunities

are adaptive, meaning we often develop a resistance
to specific diseases only after being exposed

to them. Which of course is not ideal all
the time, but alligators get to skip this
step.

Researchers examining blood samples from American
alligators isolated their infection fighting

white blood cells and then extracted the active
proteins working in those cells. And these

two included a special class of peptides which
seemed to have a knack for weakening the membranes

of bacteria, causing them to die. When pitted
against a wide range of bacteria including

drug-resistant MRSA, these tough little peptides
proved to be effective killers. They also

wiped out 6 of 8 strains of candida albicans,
a type of yeast infection that's particularly

troublesome for AIDS and transplant patients
with weakened immune systems. Such compounds

may also be found in similar animals, like
crocodiles, Komodo dragons, and the skins

of some frogs and toads. So far, lab trials
have shown that gator blood can kill at least

23 different strains of bacteria including
salmonella, e.coli, staph, and strep infections

AND even a strain of HIV. For now, scientists
are working to find the exact chemical structures

at work in four of these promising chemicals
and pinpoint which types are best at killing

which microbes. One problem so far: high concentrations
of gator blood serum have already been found

to be so powerful that they are toxic to human
cells. So other biologists are taking a different

approach in the search for the next generation
of antibiotics.

Rather than looking at other animals, they're
exploring strange, new places, like cave soils

and deep-sea sediments. Researchers have recently
discovered evidence of promising new fungi

strains living way down in hundred million
year old nutrient-starved sediments in the

Pacific Ocean. Everyone thought this was a
near-dead zone for life, too harsh and remote

an environment for something like fungi to
survive in. Just a decade ago, the only living

things known to inhabit such deep sediment
layers were single-celled bacteria and archaea,

organisms known to flourish in extreme environments.
But while examining dredged up sediments from

as deep as 127 meters into the sea floor,
scientists found fungi of at least eight different

types, four of which they successfully cultured
in the lab. Some of the fungi even belonged

to the genus Penicillium, which we have to
thank for the development of penicillin. Now,

we're not exactly sure how old these fungi
are, but they are definitely quite old and

maybe, more importantly, they appear to have
been living in isolation for eons. If that's

the case, they may have evolved specific and
unusual defenses against bacteria, which,

just like their penicillin kin in that famous
petri dish, could end up being a new and powerful

source of antibiotics.
And there's one more strategy that scientists

are using, one that works in espionage as
well as in medicine. And that is seeing what

the enemy is up to.
While exploring life in strange new places

around the world, some biologists are looking
for bacteria that have never been exposed

to our drugs, but still appear to be naturally
resistant to them.

Wherever we find the most naturally resistant
bacteria, we might also find natural antibiotics

that we never knew about.
And here, one of the most promising leads

is again in one of the hardest-to-reach places:
New Mexico's Lechuguilla cave, a place that

was isolated from all human contact until
it was discovered in the 1980's.

One of the many fascinating things that scientists
have discovered here is that the cave bacteria

seem to be resistant to everything.
Even though they've never been exposed to

us or our drugs, all of the bacteria have
proven to be resistant to at least one major

antibiotic, and many tend to fend off more
than a dozen of the most powerful antimicrobials

we have. This suggests to scientists that
the bacteria have evolved to be this way because

they live in an environment that's rich in
naturally occurring antibiotics, ones that

the germs we live with up here on the surface
have never encountered.

Now we just have to find out what exactly
those compounds are.

So look, I'm not going to lie to you: we have
a lot of work to do.

While we might discover a new super-drug lurking
in a cave or under the sea or in a cockroach's

head, there's a big difference between finding
a substance that cleans house in a petri dish

and actually putting a new antibiotic in the
vein of a human patient.

So the bummer is, as promising as some of
these bold new discoveries may be, none of

them has yet yielded an actual marketable
drug.

Still, there's a long list of successful antibiotics
that we've managed to derive from strange

sources, starting with Dr. Fleming's rogue
fungus.

So if we keep exploring strange new places
and studying how other animals deal with the

problems we're facing, we just might find
the next penicillin before the superbugs get
the best of us.

Thanks for watching this SciShow Infusion,
especially to our Subbable subscribers. To

learn how you can support us in exploring
the world, just go to Subbable.com. And as

always, if you want to keep getting smarter
with us, you can go to YouTube.com/SciShow
and subscribe.

title: Cockroaches, Alligators & Other Weird Sources of New Drugs
